Such a World-Honored One, having abandoned the pleasures of kingship, having given up the wealth, happiness, and freedom of a wheel-turning king as if discarding poisoned food, having abandoned all of his sixty thousand most beautiful and perfect consorts, he has gone forth and dwells in the forest.
In the assembly of sages there was a sage named Narada. Seeing the World-Honored One, he was overjoyed and praised the Tathagata with wonderful verses, saying:
In the blue forest, who's radiance is like molten gold,
Like pure lapis lazuli, like the sun emerging from clouds and mountains?
When the great sage and the assembly of sages heard this, they were delighted and opened their eyes. They all joined their palms and wanted to go to where the Buddha was.
At that time, the Buddha said to the bhikshus:
You bhikshus see such sages in Jambudvipa, bound by their feet and hands, hanging themselves from trees, fasting and abstaining from food, wearing bark clothes, lying in the dust and dirt.

If they are on a rock, some use their two hands to gather food and eat it with their hands open. Some eat wind. Some fast for fifteen days. Some fast for a month. Their hair, beard, nails, and toenails are all long and sharp.

They read and recited at the three times of dawn, noon, and dusk. Some had the wealth of a noble family, some had the wealth of merit. Having first enchanted the objects, they placed them in the fire and made offerings to the fire.
Some slept on the ground, some in the open, some under trees. Some hung themselves by their hands from trees while sleeping, some slept squatting like that, some slept in the water like that.

Some scorched their bodies with the five heats, some lay down scorching themselves by bringing their bodies close to the fire, some lay down in a great flame sheltered from the wind, some lay down on thorns, some scorched themselves in the sun.

Experiencing suffering and seeking blessings, they deceived themselves and their bodies, staying wherever they found a place. The superiority of their family lineage was enough for them, it was enough to please them, they were far from the unsurpassed wisdom.
Bhiká¹£us!
This great sage was unable to know the way out of birth and death.

At that time, those bhiká¹£us took refuge in the TathÄgata and said:
World-Honored One!
Our pure practice is truly complete, harmonious and in accord, and we have attained freedom from birth and existence.

Those great sages such as Vyaá¹£a, out of fear of the power of the arhats' virtue and valor, looked on with composure and respect, with a one-pointed mind. Together with their retinue of sages, they gathered their long hair in a box, tied their bodies with a good rope, their complexion was not white, their bodily demeanor was upright, their two eyes were yellow, their hair was unshiny, their hair was tied together in a knot, the mass was not one, they held a three-pronged staff, the contents of their placed vase were the ugliest in the world, and they were all skillful in various languages and accomplished in speech.
They walked through the air and arrived before the TathÄgata, saying:
World-Honored One!
You should know the meaning of this. For what reason have I and my retinue come here now?
The Buddha said:
Great sage!
I know all that is born and all dharmas.
At that time, the venerable Ä€nanda said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
Such a great sage surrounded by sages, with right knowledge in the mind, various kinds of knowledge, subtle knowledge, exhaustive knowledge, knowing without fear, long hair unkempt -
who is this person?
The Buddha said:
Ananda!
This is a great sage named VyÄsa.
The Dharma of the brahmins is what he practices. He composes the four Vedas, is well-versed in phonology, and knows various scripts.
Then all the arhat people, having seen the great sage VyÄsa, had this thought:
That person undergoes suffering, diligently upholds precepts, but what does he gain?
This Vyaá¹£a has not yet attained liberation from the suffering of birth and death.
That arhat thought like this:
If this Vyaá¹£a comes to where the Buddha is, how will he ask questions?
Will he ask about causes and conditions?
Or will he ask about no-self?
At that time, Vyaá¹£a asked the World-Honored One, saying:
The Buddha's appearance in the world is difficult.
Now the assembly of sages has come together here. I have a few difficult questions. I only wish that you would stay and explain them for me.
The Buddha said:
Great sage!
Ask whatever you wish. Ask whatever you think of. I will explain it for you.
At that time, Vyaá¹£a asked, saying:
World-Honored One!
What is giving?
Why give?ğŸ”½What is the meaning of giving?

Is it a visible accumulation of form and substance?
Or is it invisible?
Where is the giver's merit of giving?
Is it in the recipient?
Or is it in the giver?
How is it that after the World-Honored One entered nirvana, offerings made to stupas and so forth can still bring about rewards?
When the Buddha entered nirvana, who was the recipient?
At that time, the World-Honored One said to the great sage VyÄsa:
The question you have asked is extremely subtle. Your eloquence is inconceivable, and you are able to ask such questions.

At that time, the elder ÅšÄriputra, with white hair and wrinkled face, his eyebrows hanging down to cover his face, raised one eyebrow and, drawing in his breath, contemplated and considered carefully.
Having seen this, he said:

This great sage VyÄsa has a great reputation - all people know and speak of him. How could he not know, like an ignorant child lacking wisdom, to abandon speaking of causes and conditions, abandoning speaking of selflessness, the various profound dharmas, the various good and wise words, and ask such a question about the dharma of giving?
At that time, the venerable Ä€nanda bowed his head to the Buddha's feet and said:
World-Honored One!

World-Honored One!

ÅšÄriputra!
Your words are too abrupt and your mind does not contemplate.
Elder ÅšÄriputra!
Do not speak like this, it is not appropriate.
If it were so, then my disciples would not be appropriate.
If someone were to ask me and I had my disciples explain, it would not be appropriate, and some people would say:
'That TathÄgata is not omniscient.
' Some people would say:
'When the sage Vasiá¹£á¹­ha went to ask the TathÄgata, he himself could not explain and sent his disciples to explain.'
Or some people would say:

At that time, those bhiká¹£us gave rise to a pure mind of faith towards the World-Honored One and said:
World-Honored One!

At that time, the World-Honored One said to the great sage VyÄsa:
Listen to the rewards of giving and the divisions of giving.
What is the meaning of giving?
After giving, one eats and purifies oneself. After giving, the rewards turn, so it is called giving.
For what reason is one called a donor?
One who asks like this, great sage, should listen.
If a person has possessions, faith arises in them. After faith arises, they entrust their wealth to others and send them to other countries to give.
That person gives, and the owner of the wealth obtains blessings, not the blessings of the giver.
Although the one sent gives with possessions, they are not the one who relinquishes.
If a person uses their own possessions and gives with their own hands, they are the one who relinquishes and also the donor.
Great sage, know that there are thirty-three impure forms of giving.
What are the thirty-three?
First, there are those who give with a crooked mind and inverted views, without pure faith. Such giving is not pure giving.
Second, there are those who give in order to repay kindness, but that is not giving.
Third, there are those who give without a compassionate mind, which is also not giving.
Fourth, there are those who give out of lust, which is also not giving.
Fifth, there are those who give to fire, which is also not giving.
Sixth, there are those who give to water, which is also not giving.
Seventh, there are those who give rise to this thought:
'I give to the king, hoping the king will remember me.'
Giving like this is not pure giving.
Eighth, there are those who give out of fear of thieves, and such giving is also not pure giving.
There are also five kinds of things that are given away that are not pure giving.
What are the five?
First, giving poison is not a pure giving.
Second, giving knives is not a pure giving.
Third, teaching people to take meat and give it away is not a pure giving.

Fourth, if someone equally gives to a group of people who are under someone else's control, gathering them together to raise and nurture them in the hope of getting their strength, it is not a pure giving.
Fifth, if someone gives away wealth for the sake of fame, it is not a pure giving.
Fourteenth, if someone gives things to entertainers for the sake of singing and playing, it is not a pure giving.
Fifteenth, if someone breaks up their wealth at the end of the year or month, it is not a pure giving.
Sixteenth, if someone gives away wealth for the sake of a house, it is not a giving.
Seventeen, someone uses other people's property to give to others through the connection of good friends, which is not pure giving.
Eighteen, someone may have fields, houses, grain piles, or wheat piles that are eaten by deer, birds, rats, etc., without a pure mind, which is not pure giving.
Nineteen, someone gives things to craftsmen for the sake of learning how to make things, such as this kind of giving is not pure giving.
Twenty, someone has a sick body and, fearing the end of life, gives things to a doctor, which is not pure giving.
Twenty-one, if someone beats or scolds others and then regrets and feels ashamed, giving things to them, it is not pure giving.
Twenty-two, if someone gives and then gives rise to doubt in their mind:
'Will there be a reward or not?
' Giving like this is not pure giving.
The twenty-third is, if a person, after giving, regrets in their heart, such a giver is not a pure giver.
The twenty-fourth is, if a person, after giving things to others, thinks like this:
'If there are people who take my things, they all belong to me, they are held by me.'
Such a giver is not a pure giver.
The twenty-fifth is, if a person, after giving, thinks like this:
'Such giving and merit only belong to my body, not to others.'

Twenty-sixth, if an old person gives away their possessions, but not in middle age or later when they are sick and dying, when death is imminent, when the veins are about to be severed, when they are afflicted with suffering and about to enter the path of death, without a pure mind, without a mind of faith and purity, the messengers of Yama see this and laugh, while their siblings and relatives cry and grieve. Giving away possessions at such a time is not pure giving.
Twenty-seventh, if a person gives away their possessions for the sake of fame:
'In this way, my name will be heard throughout other countries, in such and such a country, in such and such a city, as the great patron of giving.
' Such giving is not pure giving.

Twenty-eighth, if one gives to others while harboring mutual hatred, seeing others give away their possessions and practice giving extensively, seeing this, one is arrogant and cannot bear it. Because of jealousy towards them, one gives away their possessions, which is not pure giving.

Twenty-ninth, for the sake of coveting other's women and for the sake of family lineage, one abandons pearls, gold, silver, diamonds, lapis lazuli, silk garments, cotton, and makes bedding. Abandoning such things is not pure giving.
Thirtieth, some people think like this when abandoning things to give to others:
'I have no children or offspring, but I am very wealthy. I should abandon things and practice giving.'
Such giving is not pure giving.
Thirty-first, if someone gives rise to discrimination in their mind and thinks like this:
'If I give to this person, I will have merit. If I give to that person, I will have no merit.'
Such giving is not pure giving.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Thirty-second, if a person gives, abandoning poverty, tattered clothes, and dirt, to those with abundant happiness and great wealth, it is not pure giving.
Thirty-third, if someone hopes for beautiful flowers and fruits, and gives away things, it is not pure giving.

Great Sage, you should know that these thirty-three defiled and tainted acts of giving away wealth and objects, the rewards for that giving are like planting seeds in salty soil, rotting and not growing.
Great Sage, you should know that such a person is not not giving, but does not obtain the rewards.
Furthermore, Great Sage!
It is like a person who obtains seeds from anywhere and plants them in uncultivated fields.
Those seeds and the earth elements rely on each other, and need the rain from heaven. The seeds change and decay, and although sprouts grow, they do not get flowers and fruits;
This part of giving does not get flowers and fruits, it is also like this.
Having said this, the sage VyÄsa joined his palms towards the Buddha and said:
The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, the Omniscient One, has spoken the Dharma of giving with appropriate words, already benefiting and bringing peace and joy to sentient beings.
Moreover, World-Honored One!
How can one's giving not lose its fruits?
There are people who keep precepts and those who do not. If both are given to, what does this mean?
The Buddha said:
Great sage!
You should now listen well to the Dharma of the fruits of giving.
If one has faith in one's heart and gives everything, it is called giving;
If one practices giving without fearing the future and without despising others, it is called giving.

Great sage, you should know that if there are people who do not discriminate between those with and without blessings, whether they keep precepts or not, with a faithful heart and open eyes, giving rise to love and affection, they give away their possessions, always universally contemplating all sentient beings.
Great Sage, you should know that such a person is a generous patron.
Great Sage, you should know that there are five kinds of generosity that fulfill the generous patron.
What are the five?

First, timely giving; second, giving to those who serve; third, giving to the sick and those who care for the sick; fourth, giving to those who are vessels of the Dharma; fifth, giving to those who wish to travel to other countries;
these are the five.
There are also five kinds of generosity.
What are the five?

First, the generosity of the Dharma; second, the generosity of material resources; third, the generosity of dwellings; fourth, the generosity of lamps and light; fifth, the generosity of fragrant garlands;
these are the five kinds.
The Great Sage asked:
What is pure generosity?
The Buddha said:
Great Sage!
If a person has faith and, out of compassion for sentient beings, always gives with a joyful mind, all of that is pure;
if one wishes for liberation, such generosity will be pure.
There are also five kinds of unsurpassed giving.
What are the five?

First, giving to the TathÄgata is unsurpassed; second, giving to the Saá¹…gha is unsurpassed; third, giving to a Dharma vessel is unsurpassed; fourth, giving to one's parents is unsurpassed; fifth, giving to a king who has lost his position and is poor is unsurpassed;
Giving like this is the highest giving.
If one gives to the elderly, the orphaned, the sick, and the destitute, this is great giving;
If one is angry with the king, and is abandoned, bound, or about to be killed,
If one rescues them from all kinds of urgent difficulties, disregarding one's own life, and gives up one's wealth, this is great giving;
Giving medicine to the sick, this is great giving;
If one gives to the Saá¹…gha of fully ordained monks and nuns at the proper time, this is great giving;
Giving to those who seek wisdom, this is great giving;
If one gives to frightened animals, such as foxes, crows, and deer, this is a great act of giving.
If a poor person gives according to their needs, this is a great act of giving.
Great Sage, you should know that this is a great act of giving, which should always be practiced correctly.
If someone is sent by others to give things in charity, they will have a pure mind and will also obtain the merit of giving.
If someone sees others giving in charity and rejoices in their heart, they will also obtain the merit of giving.
If a person encourages giving or if a person gives things, such people will all obtain great blessings.
Furthermore, Great Sage!
As you have asked,
'How can one obtain the reward of blessings by making offerings to stupas after the World-Honored One enters nirvana?'
Great sage, listen. If someone makes offerings after I enter nirvana, and if someone makes offerings to me now while I am in the present world, the rewards they obtain in blessings are equal.
Why is this?
The Dharma body of the TathÄgata is not a physical body.
If someone makes offerings to me now in the present or makes offerings after my nirvÄá¹‡a, because their minds are equal, they obtain blessings without difference.
Great sage, you should know that the wheel-turning king issues edicts to all the countries:
'All people from today onwards should not kill, and should not speak falsely.'
If there is a person who hears the king's edict and, although not seeing the king, still well protects the king's edict,
such a person, although not making offerings to the wheel-turning king's body, the king gives rise to joy in their mind.
Such a person well protects the king's edict, and because of the good cause and condition of not killing, they are reborn in the heavens.
Great Sage, you should know that if a person does not see my physical form and characteristics, and does not learn the precepts, what will they attain?
If a person sees me but has wrong views, like Devadatta who entered hell;
If a person, after my nirvÄá¹‡a, learns the precepts well, they will be superior, you should know.
Great Sage, you should know that now my form is supreme, I have realized omniscience, and I can make even unbelieving beings learn the precepts, let alone those with faith?
If a person, after my nirvÄá¹‡a, makes offerings, it will be no different from making offerings now.
Great Sage, listen, as you have asked:
'Where is the merit of giving?'
Asking like this is like reeds and grasses densely intertwined, a fire arises in them, and when rain falls, it immediately sinks into them.

In the same way, whatever the donor, the perfection of giving and the combination of merit and virtue, when the rain of faith falls, in the same way, that merit and virtue depend on the donor, not going elsewhere.
Great Sage, you should know that such meritorious giving is not a place of accumulation, not a form or appearance.
Having given in this way, when the giver dies, the merit of giving does not leave, like a shadow following a form. This is called the giver obtaining the fruit of meritorious retribution.
The fruit of merit is not lost, like sugarcane, reeds, or peaches. If they are not pressed, their juice cannot be obtained, but if they are pressed, it can be obtained.
It is not that in the sugarcane or reeds or peaches there is a juice that can be seen assembled in front of one, nor is it in the joints, nor is it without juice.
In the same way, the wealth given, the reward for such giving to that donor, is not in the hands, not in the mind, not in the belly, but the reward for giving does not leave the giver;
Just as the juice is inseparable from sugarcane or grapes.
Thus, the rewards of giving are inseparable from the giver. Until they are ripe, they are not received. When the life force is not exhausted, one does not obtain the rewards of giving.
It is like the seed of the king of trees, the nyagrodha. The seed is tiny, and when planted in the ground it is invisible, but when the tree grows it becomes visible.
The blessings of giving by the giver are also like this. When they come together and ripen, one obtains the rewards.
It is like a merchant who carries a small amount with him to a great city - the merits of that city, with a small amount of goods, he obtains much and is fully satisfied.
Giving is also like this. Although the giving is small, the obtained rewards of blessings are great.
It is also like a bee collecting the flavors of flowers without harming the flowers. The giver is like this.
Whatever giving one makes, the power of the obtained rewards of blessings is that of the giver?
Thus, great sage!
The power of the blessings of giving by the giver.
As for the donor, because they give themselves, they are called the donor.
What is a recipient?
Accepting what others give, able to digest others' things, therefore called a recipient.
He also asked:
'What is the merit of giving?
' In the world, able to save, able to protect, able to bring satisfaction, obtaining a human or heavenly body, therefore called merit.
As for the other world, it is transmitted in sequence to the body of the next world, therefore called the other world.
At that time, the sage VyÄsa said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
I am free from doubts, and have certainty regarding the division of giving, but I have another doubt.
World-Honored One!
How does this consciousness operate within the body?
How does the consciousness see?
How does it give rise to craving and pleasure in the body?
The Buddha said:
Great Sage!

It is like a king dwelling in the city. Fearing the enemy army, he first digs moats and surrounds the city. He prepares food, bows, arrows, swords, shields, and various weapons. He gathers many brave and able fighters and sets up a banner for the able warriors. He also gathers many young and able men and provides them with food and provisions. He orders the wine shops to prepare good wine.
He supports the renunciant practitioners and makes offerings to them, accepting people with good wealth and goods.
Having done so, he proclaims and orders:
Abide peacefully and do not move. Each of you should arm yourselves with weapons, hold bows and arrows in your hands, wear armor and helmets, and draw your swords to be on guard.
Having given such instructions, the enemy army arrives, with many elephants and horses.
At that time, the king comforts the troops and says:
Exhaust your strength and do not be afraid. If there are any weak points in the city walls, you should defend them well. Do this every day.
In this way, until their merit is exhausted, they will be defeated by the armies of others, suddenly defeated and scattered, abandoning their country.
Consciousness is also like this. Dwelling in the body-city, the king among the sense-bases, seeing the army of impermanence about to arrive, fear arises.

Immediately, it creates the moat of faith, repairs the steep cliffs of the realm, dons the armor of mindfulness, and exerts diligent effort. The treasury of Dharma becomes alcohol, and the mind-horse is well-tamed.
At that time, it thus commands and warns the sense-bases, making them do what should be done:

'If the army of impermanence, with great power and immeasurable strength, comes to attack the body-city, quickly don the armor of giving, quickly take up the sword of wisdom, place the mechanism of shame and conscience in the proper position, and uphold the true precepts. Abide thus.
' The army of impermanence suddenly arrives and immediately engages in battle, opposing each other.
The army of impermanence wins and consciousness then abandons the body.
Just as a king abandons a city and leaves, so does consciousness.

When the body is combined in the realm of the faculties and elements, and when the six sense bases are destroyed, it abandons that bodily city, just as a king who destroys a city abandons it and flees.
That king, having thus abandoned the city, relies on another city;
consciousness is also like this, abandoning this body and grasping another body.
One should know that this consciousness is no different from a king.
At that time, the sage VyÄsa said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
How does consciousness know whether the body has merit or not?
How does this consciousness know:
'I abandon this body'?
The Buddha said:
Great Sage!
It is like a traveler who encounters a great flood. The water is swollen, and in order to cross that water, he boards a large raft.
The water being long, the waves are agitated and turbulent, and it is also very turbid, with many evil insects, namely nÄgas, Å›uÅ›umÄras, water snakes, and evil turtles.
There is a great evil wind that blows and swirls wildly, but relying on the raft, one can reach the other shore safely and without want.
Such a person, having escaped from that evil water, that great fearful and evil place, circles the raft three times, and towards that wooden raft gives rise to a loving mind.
Having given rise to a loving mind, he thinks like this:
'Excellent!
This raft is able to cause me to cross this great water.'
Thus it is, Great Sage!
Moreover, there are other beings with merit whose consciousness, after the body dies, thinks like this:
'Because of this body of mine, I will be reborn in the good destinies, in the heavens.
I have obtained benefit from my human body that is not in vain. This dead body of mine is like a sturdy raft, able to cause me to cross the great waters of the evil destinies.'
This body of mine is greatly beneficial and worthy of offerings. Such a body does not deceive me, and within the faults of birth and death, it gives me heavenly realms.'
Having had such thoughts, he then gives rise to a mind of affection towards that body.
That body is like a raft. Having abandoned that body, he goes towards the other world.

If there is a person whose body lacks merit, that person's mind and consciousness are like a person whose body is a rotten raft crossing a great body of water, and that raft sometimes emerges and sometimes sinks.
That person is fearful and gives rise to doubts:
'I will soon die.'
Such a person, relying on that rotten raft, is greatly afraid, following the current downstream, to a place of great fear with lions, tigers, and other ferocious beasts, and then manages to cross.
After that person has thus crossed, he gives rise to a mind of anger towards that rotten raft, and scolds that rotten raft, saying such words:
'This is a place of inverted evil conduct, with this water overflowing, many waves, and impurity.
How is it that I have ended up in such an evil place?
What power do I have over this rotting raft?'
And so he abandoned the raft.
It is just like this.
The consciousness of sentient beings, relying on a body without merit, flows down and falls into hell.
Reproaching this body, he says like this:
'What power have I obtained?
I have already received such an evil body.
Such a body is like a donkey. I carry this body as if carrying a donkey.
I am now very evil. Because of this rotting body, I reach the gate of hell, just like a lotus bound by its own thread.'
Great Sage, you should know that consciousness is also like this.
If there is good merit, it is like relying on a good raft to cross through birth and death;
If there is no merit, it is like relying on a rotting raft and falling into evil paths.
These two kinds of bodies, one with merit and one without merit, should be understood in this way.
Moreover, this consciousness abandons this body and obtains a second body. In the first seven days in the womb, it remembers and knows like this:
'I have fallen from such and such a place and come here.'
It can also remember and know the previous karma it created:
'I created this karma.'
If it created good karma, the mind will give rise to joy.

Having stayed in the womb, the mother's mind is joyful and smiling, with many excellent characteristics - the face has a smiling expression, no ugly moles are born - the face has a superior complexion, and when moving, it mostly uses the right foot to step on the ground with heavy pressure, without any cause it rubs the right side with the hand, it likes fresh white clothes, and when wearing them, it is then dignified.
When sentient beings have such meritorious consciousness, staying in the mother's womb, such characteristics appear.
Great Sage, you should know that if a being lacks merit and wisdom, when first receiving birth, within the first seven days, it will be able to remember:
'I have fallen from such-and-such a place and come to be born here.'
It will also be able to remember the karma it previously created, thinking like this:
'How did I create evil karma?'
Thinking like this, the mind will be sorrowful;
because the mind is sorrowful, the mother's appearance will be outwardly manifested.

That being without merit and virtue, without good, while dwelling in the mother's womb, will have an external appearance, with a foul-smelling body and also emaciated, with a sorrowful mind, frequently spitting without stopping, with a wrinkled face and angry eyes.
Such a being, while first in the womb, will cause that family to suffer misfortune and become ill.
Such an evil-karmic being without merit and virtue, when about to emerge from the womb, may either kill the mother or die in the womb.
Beings without merit and virtue have such characteristics.
At that time, the sage VyÄsa said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!

What does it see and know?
The Buddha said:
Great Sage!
That consciousness first arises with such memories:

Seeing places for playing and enjoying in the forest, palaces, pavilions, water flowing on the ground, flat and vast fields, various houses, and in this JambudvÄ«pa, many beloved people, parents, and siblings.
Having seen this, one gives rise to extreme love.
Merit and virtue gather, mutually embracing each other. There are those who give gifts and those who receive gifts.
One is able to know the affairs of one's past lives, remembering countless hundreds of lifetimes and countless thousands of lifetimes. That consciousness thus repeatedly remembers.
Having remembered, the mind gives rise to loving joy, and one is able to know like this:
'This mother of mine has already been my mother for five hundred lifetimes in the past.
Having thus remembered in their minds, they will not delight in being born there, their minds will become detached, and they will think like this:
'I have repeatedly been born and died in this place. Now I finally do not need birth and death, I do not need to be included in existence.'
Having said this, the sage VyÄsa asked:
World-Honored One!
Can such consciousness become detached from birth and death?
The Buddha said:
Great Sage!
This is neither the time nor the place.
At that time, that consciousness is formless and invisible, without light.
In this way, the realm of consciousness cannot become detached from this place, and within conditioned existence it is not unborn.
If it were so, all sentient beings - those with merit and those without merit - would attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
The meaning is like this, Great Sage, you should know.
If that mind consciousness thinks like this, that consciousness will have such superior power, and one should know it is not the power of the body.
Why is it called consciousness?
Because it accumulates, consciousness thinks, and because it knows, it is called wisdom. Therefore, it is called consciousness-consciousness.
The meaning of consciousness is like this. Great Sage, you should know.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Protecting all enemies, accumulating to form afflictions,
There is knowing, there is not knowing, delusion and wisdom are mixed in practice.
Views, arrogance, ignorance, and so forth, all are known by consciousness,
These three are inseparable from consciousness, they do not exist separately elsewhere.
Consciousness should be spoken of in terms of a pair, a single wheel is not a chariot,
Two wheels cannot move by themselves;ğŸ”½The chariot's spokes and rim are combined, these two wheels are in harmony,
And are further bound together with ropes, in this way it becomes a moving chariot.
Thus, this body is a chariot, composed of the combination of elements,
And further, there is the combination of faculties, consciousness sees this bodily chariot.
The combination of veins, joints, etc., the throat, veins, and root bindings,
Hair, bones, teeth, head, etc., covered by nails and skin,
The sides, intestines, stomach, heart, and lungs,
All of these combined, complete, are called the body.
The king of consciousness takes the body as a chariot, in the chariot of the body, one moves and sits,
Knowing all dharmas, this is called consciousness.
Furthermore, Great Sage!
This consciousness is subtle, without form, without substance, and cannot be seen.
Consciousness is not form, not blue or other colors.
In form, there are no faculties. If consciousness is apart from the faculties, then there is no object.
If a person's mind is agitated, fearful, or doubtful, all of this is the power of consciousness.

The Buddha said:
Great Sage!
You should listen well, and I will explain it to you.

Ordinary beings regress from their inherent nature. If they give rise to merit and virtue, this Dharma is known only by the Omniscient One, not by those with the five supernormal powers. May the World-Honored One,
please explain well for me, so that my retinue may greatly obtain good benefits.
The World-Honored One is the sun of omniscience, dispelling the darkness of afflictions.
May the World-Honored One,
please explain this inherent nature - the inherent nature of sentient beings - that causes them to regress and be reborn in the heavens.
The Buddha said:
Great sage!
Now is the right time. I will explain for you.
Great sage, you should know that if a person offers flowers and garlands with a joyful mind, in accord with faith, upon the end of their life they will be reborn in the Heaven Adorned with Garlands.
Moreover, great sage!
When a person is about to die, their body has a pleasant fragrance, which is the fragrance of these flowers.
Also, when about to die, they see flower nets of various colors above, which scatter over that person.
At that time, relatives, parents, brothers, and other family members hold flowers and incense to make offerings to them, crying and wailing.
At that time, the person's complexion is lustrous, their eyes do not move, their hands and feet are straight, and they pass away like this.
When they are about to die, they see superior signs, namely, they see hills, see themselves adorned with garlands, and see hundreds of thousands of beautiful women surrounding heavenly palaces.
Having seen this, they tell their brothers, relatives, and others:
'In my dream, I saw hills, various jewels, various adornments, and various flowers scattered.'
If the patient speaks like this, one should know that this sign indicates that after death they will be reborn in the Heaven Adorned with Garlands.
When that person is about to die, they see their parents engaging in sexual intercourse, and upon seeing this, they are born.
Moreover, at that time, the CÄmara gods have two kinds of faculties that unite and engage in sexual activity, just like men in JambudvÄ«pa, with one superior dharma: impurity does not come out.
When their minds are aroused, they know each other, and their bodies unite. A loving wind comes out and they experience sexual pleasure.
At that time, they stay in the womb of the celestial maiden for seven days.
After seven days, they are born from the right side.
At the time of birth, there is a heavenly fragrance that is most delightful. Various flowers are tied into garlands and grow on their chests.
At that time, there is a wonderful fragrance that pervades a full yojana, spreading everywhere with the wind.

At that time, there also appeared various garlands, namely white, black, yellow, red, vaiá¸Å«rya color, color of the juice of the JambÅ« River, pure and excellent padma color, various mixed colors, copper color, and fire color.
Such wonderful garlands, until death, do not wither or dry up, and always have a good fragrance.
For this reason, it is called the adornment of garlands.
In the heavenly palace of the Heaven of Adorned with Garlands, there is a wonderful heavenly tree, neither long nor short, whose sap is extremely sweet, tasting like nectar.
Its branches hang down and are pure, and various forests are gathered everywhere.
That tree has fruits that are a combination of eight parts, corresponding to the heavenly flavors.
The shape and size of those fruits are like pÄ«lu fruits. According to what food the heavenly being thinks of in his mind, he can obtain it all in those fruits.
One should know that the heavenly being eats such fruits, and it is not called solid food.
In that place, far away from thorns and brambles, it is adorned with wonderful flowers.
There is also a place with green soft grass.
There is also a place covered with golden sand, with golden horns protruding.
There are also places to lie down, with various bedding naturally provided.
There are also celestial maidens, pure and spotless, adorned with wonderful garments, raising one eyebrow and laughing playfully, with various garments adorning their bodies.
Moreover, in that place, the supreme bliss is complete, whether walking or standing.
In that heaven, the lifespan is two hundred years. When life is about to end, there are five signs.
What are the five?
First, the branches and heart of the tree that the celestial beings rely on wither and droop, and its flowers lose their fragrance;
second, they do not delight in that tree;
third, their garlands wither;
fourth, the cool celestial wind changes to a hot touch;
Fifth, the celestial maidens, feeling pity, all became sorrowful. With one voice, they spoke a verse, saying:
Endowed with heavenly sweet fruits, abundant with various heavenly trees,
With many celestial maidens, a place of heavenly supreme bliss,
The heavenly merits are exhausted, abandoned and departed.
Those celestial maidens surrounded the celestial son, raised their voices and cried out, saying:
Impermanence is extremely evil, without any compassionate mind.
Such a celestial son has a loving mind, but his life is not independent. He will fall from this place. May the celestial child be quickly reborn among humans.
Having said this, the celestial maidens were distressed. The body of that celestial son became feverish all over.

Having become feverish, the body became completely ablaze. A single flame of fire arose and he immediately fell from that place - although his body was burning, he did not experience any suffering or distress.
After they have retreated, they will see their human parents united.
Having seen this, they will then take rebirth.
Great Sage, you should know that when the celestial son adorned with garlands is born, how does he dwell in the womb?
If he dwells in the womb, there will be excellent signs.

If he dwells in the womb, the mother will love fragrances, delight in flower garlands, enjoy various fruits, green forests, and groves, experience mental ease, and be fully endowed with all pleasures, with a body free from fatigue.

Moreover, because of the dwelling of that fortunate child in the womb, there are also good signs. Either one dreams of a city with various precious things, a place for buying and selling, and various flower garlands scattered in the streets.
You should know that the mother has such signs.
Furthermore, Great Sage!
In this way, after the child has retreated from the celestial realm adorned with garlands, having been born among humans, if he sees garlands, he will give rise to a mind of supreme love.

They enjoy fresh white clothes, have a distinctive body color, lack sharp wisdom, do not love excessive desire, enjoy much play and amusement, are quick in all activities such as walking and standing, enjoy seeing places of play, like fine clothes, love beautiful forests, and when seeing others' wealth and abundance, they devise many means to hope to obtain it.
Great Sage, you should know that when the Heaven Adorned with Garlands falls and is reborn among humans, they have such characteristics.
